states: Aguascalientes; Chiapas; Chihuahua; Colima; Ciudad de México; Durango; Guanajuato; Guerrero; Hidalgo; Jalisco; Estado de México; Michoacán; Morelos; Nayarit; Nuevo León; Oaxaca; Puebla; Querétaro; San Luis Potosí; Sinaloa; Sonora; Tabasco; Tamaulipas; Veracruz; Yucatán; Zacatecas
geo_region: Widespread across Mexico (multiple regions and biomes)
Terrain: Desert and dry shrubland on well drained sandy or rocky soils; widely cultivated on valley floors and gentle slopes
mezcal_use: Main cultivated mezcal agave; 6-8 year maturity; very widely planted
producers: "Ilegal Mezcal,Real Minero,Mezcal Vago,Paquera,QuiQuiRiQui,El Jolgorio,The Producer,Victorioso,Mezcal de Leyendas,Lalocura,Grulani,Mezcal Colores,Erstwhile,Dixeebe Mezcal,Lamata"
description: Espadín is the agave behind most people’s first mezcal, and most of what’s poured. It’s responsible for at least 80% of mezcal sold.

geo_region: Central Oaxaca, southern Puebla and west-central Veracruz dry forests (Tehuacán-Cuicatlán and adjacent)
Terrain: Semi arid highlands on rocky slopes and cliffs; tropical forest at lower elevations and oak forest at higher elevations
mezcal_use: High value wild and semi managed mezcal; sweet, floral spirits
producers: "Del Maguey,Rey Campero,El Jolgorio,Cinco Sentidos,Real Minero,QuiQuiRiQui,Gracias a Dios,Victorioso,Mezcal de Leyendas,Creador,NETA,Cortijo,Lalocura,Grulani,Carreño,Koch,Siete Misterios,Marca Negra,La Medida,Entre Maguey,Mezcal Colores,Erstwhile,Bozal"
description: Tobalá is typically a smaller, compact plant, harvest often means careful, hands-on work. It's low profile in the landscape, big payoff in the bottle.

geo_region: Tehuacán-Cuicatlán Valley (Oaxaca and Puebla)
Terrain: Tropical dry forest and xeric scrub on rocky cliffs and canyon walls; well drained stony soils
mezcal_use: Long maturing wild mezcal agave; intense savoury herbal mezcals
producers: "Del Maguey,Gracias a Dios,The Producer,Rey Campero,El Jolgorio,Gusto Historico,NETA,Grulani,Carreño,Koch,Marca Negra,La Medida,El Buho,Mezcal Colores,Erstwhile,Bozal,Dixeebe Mezcal,Divinos Ancestros"
description: Tepextate has a marbled, sculpted look. It matures on a slow timetable, so harvesting it tends to be a patient mission.

geo_region: Oaxaca and Puebla dry valleys (Central Valleys, Mixteca, Tehuacán-Cuicatlán)
Terrain: Arid hill regions on shallow stony soils; xeric scrub and tropical dry forest on rocky slopes and canyons; often limestone
mezcal_use: Wild and semi wild mezcal agave; earthy, mineral, woody profiles
producers: "Rey Campero,Gracias a Dios,Victorioso,Mezcal de Leyendas,El Jolgorio,Cinco Sentidos,Del Maguey,Real Minero,Paquera,Gracias a Dios,Lalocura,Carreño,El Buho,Mezcal Colores,Bozal"
description: Cuishe grows in slim, column-like stalks that shoot vertical instead of spreading wide. Those narrow, upward-pointing leaves make it look a bit punk.

geo_region: Oaxaca and Puebla dry valleys (Central Valleys, Mixteca, Tehuacán-Cuicatlán)
Terrain: Arid hill regions on shallow stony soils; xeric scrub and tropical dry forest on rocky slopes and canyons; often limestone
mezcal_use: Highly prized mezcal agave; structured, mineral spirits
description: Barril is famously more barrel than bloom. Karwinskii types can grow on a stem, so harvest often means working up the stalk to get to that hefty piña.

geo_region: Oaxaca and Puebla dry valleys (Central Valleys, Mixteca, Tehuacán-Cuicatlán)
Terrain: Arid hill regions on shallow stony soils; xeric scrub and tropical dry forest on rocky slopes and canyons; often limestone
mezcal_use: Wild and semi wild mezcal; mineral profile
producers: "Cinco Sentidos,Del Maguey,Rey Campero,El Jolgorio,Gusto Historico,Gracias a Dios,Neta,Cortijo,Amarás,Koch,La Medida,Erstwhile,Bozal,Divinos Ancestros,Lamata"
description: Madrecuixe has a lean profile, narrow leaves and a poised, upright form. Looks like it’s balancing its way through a tough landscape.

geo_region: Oaxaca and Puebla dry valleys (Central Valleys, Mixteca, Tehuacán-Cuicatlán)
Terrain: Arid hill regions on shallow stony soils; xeric scrub and tropical dry forest on rocky slopes and canyons; often limestone
mezcal_use: Regional mezcal type; lean stony profile
description: Bicuixe grows a long, slender stalk with a tight rosette perched on top. It has a clean, unmistakable silhouette.

geo_region: Oaxaca and Puebla dry valleys (Central Valleys, Mixteca, Tehuacán-Cuicatlán)
Terrain: Arid hill regions on shallow stony soils; xeric scrub and tropical dry forest on rocky slopes and canyons; often limestone
mezcal_use: Common karwinskii mezcal; herbal profile
description: Tobaziche grows up on a woody stem, lifting its rosette into the air. Its narrow, dark-green leaves flare out in a tight crown.

geo_region: Central Valleys of Oaxaca; San Baltazar Guelavila; nearby communities
Terrain: Unresolved Agave sp.; typically harvested from rocky slopes and canyons in xeric scrub and tropical dry forest; terrain varies by local ID
mezcal_use: Small-batch hillside mezcal maguey; c. 7 year maturation; used for high-proof artisanal mezcal
description: Lumbre leads with looks: green blades rising from red-tinged bases, like heat just under the surface.

geo_region: High mountains of Northeastern Mexico
Terrain: High elevation mountain slopes in pine oak and cloud forest; cool humid sites with deep leaf litter and very well drained soils
mezcal_use: Occasional wild-harvest mountain mezcal; more often grown as ornamental despite good sugar content
description: Montana is built to handle rougher weather, with thick, upright leaves with pronounced teeth. Often taking well over a decade to flower.

geo_region: Central Valleys of Oaxaca; surrounding sierras
Terrain: Arid to semi arid scrub and open woodland plus disturbed ground; commonly on rocky slopes and sandy sites; frequently cultivated
mezcal_use: Huge traditional mezcal agave; big layered spirits
producers: "Cinco Sentidos,Del Maguey,Rey Campero,Paquera,QuiQuiRiQui,Gracias a Dios,Cortijo,El Jolgorio,Amarás,Koch,Siete Misterios,Real Minero,La Medida,El Buho,Dixeebe"
description: Arroqueño is a massive rosette, its leaves can wear a dusty white coat. Around twenty years to mature (longer in the wild).

geo_region: Valles Centrales (Tlacolula), Oaxaca
Terrain: Arid to semi arid scrub and open woodland plus disturbed ground; commonly on rocky slopes and sandy sites; frequently cultivated
mezcal_use: Wild mezcal agave in some regions
description: Sierra Negra spreads into a massive rosette that can reach around six to ten feet wide. Each leaf armed with teeth and a sharp tip.

geo_region: Tlacolula Valley; Ocotlán Valley; Sola de Vega (Oaxaca)
Terrain: Unresolved Agave sp.; typically harvested from rocky slopes and canyons in xeric scrub and tropical dry forest; terrain varies by local ID
mezcal_use: Hybrid or americana like mezcal agave; rich herbaceous spirits
description: Coyote is a tight rosette of slim, blade-like leaves with jagged teeth. The name “Coyote” can be used for different agaves in different places.

states: Chihuahua; Colima; Durango; Jalisco; Nayarit; Oaxaca; Puebla; Sinaloa; Sonora; Zacatecas
geo_region: Western and northwestern Mexico (Pacific slope; Sierra Madre Occidental and adjacent ranges)
Terrain: Moist mountain slopes within tropical dry forests and shrublands; well drained rocky ground
mezcal_use: One of main wild and semi cultivated mezcal species; dense oily spirits
producers: "Rey Campero,Creador,El Jolgorio,Gusto Historico,Gracias a Dios,Mezcal de Leyendas,Koch,Siete Misterios,El Buho,Dixeebe Mezcal,Divinos Ancestros"
description: Mexicano grows as a vivid green rosette, with rigid leaves packed tightly like spokes, which gives the whole plant a “mid-burst” look.

states: Colima; Durango; Jalisco; Nayarit; Sinaloa; Zacatecas
geo_region: Western Mexico (Sierra Madre Occidental and adjacent ranges)
Terrain: Montane oak and pine oak woodland on rocky slopes and ridgelines; well drained stony soils
mezcal_use: Regional mezcal species and raicilla relative; rustic profiles
description: Masparillo (a locally used agave) is a mountain plant with broad leaves lined with jagged marginal spines.

geo_region: Río Balsas basin
Terrain: Rocky slopes in oak forest and tropical dry forest; also persists in open pasture and mixed oak dry forest
mezcal_use: Flagship wild mezcal agave of Guerrero and Michoacán
producers: "Gracias a Dios,Amarás,Marca Negra,Entre Maguey,Clase Azul,Maguey Melate,Don Mateo,Hacienda de Bañuelos"
description: Agave cupreata opens into a broad rosette that can look like wings caught mid-flap, with warm, copper-leaning spines.

states: Ciudad de México; Durango; Hidalgo; Jalisco; Estado de México; Michoacán; Morelos; Sinaloa; Tlaxcala
geo_region: Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt and adjacent highlands
Terrain: High elevation pine oak and oak forests on rocky slopes and ravines; sometimes xeric scrub margins
mezcal_use: Important regional mezcal species; also domestication ancestor for A. hookeri
description: Alto grows as a big, upright rosette, about four to seven feet tall, looking like a crown. ‘Alto’ can also refer to different agaves in different places

states: Aguascalientes; Chiapas; Coahuila; Colima; Ciudad de México; Durango; Guanajuato; Hidalgo; Jalisco; Estado de México; Michoacán; Morelos; Nuevo León; Oaxaca; Puebla; Querétaro; San Luis Potosí; Tlaxcala; Veracruz; Zacatecas
geo_region: Mexican Altiplano (Central Highlands)
Terrain: Dry sunny high plateau and arid scrub on rocky limestone or chalky soils; open slopes and plains
mezcal_use: Traditional agave for pulque and regional mezcal; also fibre
producers: "Maguey Melate,Maguey Melate,The Lost Explorer,Mezcal Derrumbes,Don Ramon,Coyota,Mil Lumbres,De Matachines"
description: Salmiana is the kind of agave that fills a landscape with sheer presence, broad, heavy leaves forming a wide, sculptural rosette.

states: San Luis Potosí; Querétaro; Zacatecas; Hidalgo
geo_region: Zacatecas Plateau (Mexican Altiplano)
Terrain: High plateau semi arid scrub and open slopes on rocky often limestone soils; similar habitat to Salmiana
mezcal_use: Wild or feral plants harvested for mezcal and fibre
description: Cimarrón grows as a hefty rosette with thick leaves edged in sharp teeth and finished with a stiff terminal spine, edge-to-tip armor.

geo_region: Sierra Madre Occidental (Durango and Zacatecas highlands)
Terrain: Open rocky slopes in pine oak woodland and grasslands of the Sierra Madre; well drained stony soils
mezcal_use: Flagship mezcal agave of Durango DO; cenizo mezcals
producers: "Mezcal de Leyendas,Amarás,Clase Azul,Mezcal Derrumbes,Sacro Imperio,Mil Lumbres,Lagrimas de Dolores,Burrito Fiestero,Bozal,Lamata"
description: Cenizo Durangensis wears an ash-toned, waxy coat on its leaves. It takes its time, its climb to full size is up to twenty years.

geo_region: Sahuayo area
Terrain: Arid to semi arid scrub and disturbed ground on rocky slopes; similar habitat to Agave americana; locally variable
mezcal_use: Cultivated mezcal crop, primary agave for mezcal in Sahuayo region; cultivated with no specific IUCN status but monitored amid demand
description: Manso Sahuayo throws out long, rigid leaves in a rosette, with barbed edges and sharp tips.

geo_region: Central Valleys of Oaxaca and adjacent Puebla dry valleys
Terrain: Data limited; reported from dry rocky mountain areas in Oaxaca; likely xeric scrub and dry forest on stony slopes
mezcal_use: Rare/less common mezcal agave in Oaxaca, sometimes associated with “coyote/coyota” naming in some contexts
description: Lyobaa takes root in limestone country. The name nods to Mitla’s Zapotec name, often translated as “place of rest”.

geo_region: Sierra Madre Occidental
Terrain: Open rocky sites in pine oak forest and volcanic foothills; often on slopes and canyon walls
mezcal_use: “Churique” is used as a local name for Agave shrevei in Chihuahua and Sonoa, the spirit is sometimes referred to as “lechuguilla” (local names vary)
description: Churique is a rosette of blue-gray blades, lance-shaped leaves with big, serrated teeth.

geo_region: Tequila region
Terrain: Cultivated on well drained volcanic and red soils on plateaus and slopes in Jalisco; warm semi arid climate
mezcal_use: Main tequila species; occasionally used in mezcal in certain regions
producers: "Rey Campero,Mezcal de Leyendas,Mezcal Derrumbes,La Luna,La Leyenda,Tlamati,Pal'alma"
description: Weber Azul is blue-leaning with a tight rosette of stiff leaves and sharp edges. This tough plant belongs to more than one tradition.

states: Coahuila; Durango; Hidalgo; Nuevo León; Querétaro; San Luis Potosí; Tamaulipas
geo_region: Sierra Madre Oriental and northern highlands
Terrain: Open mountain slopes in pine oak forest at high elevation; rocky well drained soils, often under light canopy
mezcal_use: Local mezcal and regional spirits; also ornamental and forage
description: Verde is a broad, stiff green rosette, with big teeth and red-brown tips. Time to ultimate height of ten to twenty years.

states: Chihuahua; Colima; Durango; Jalisco; Nayarit; Oaxaca; Puebla; Sinaloa; Sonora; Zacatecas
geo_region: Western and northwestern Mexico (Pacific slope; Sierra Madre Occidental and adjacent ranges)
Terrain: Moist mountain slopes within tropical dry forests and shrublands; well drained rocky ground
mezcal_use: Valued for high-yield, quality mezcal in Guerrero; limited cultivation
description: Warash grows as a dense, rigid rosette that can swing from light green into darker grey-blue. Often eight to eleven years to maturity.

geo_region: Miahuatlán, Sierra Sur, Oaxaca
Terrain: Arid to semi arid scrub and open woodland plus disturbed ground; commonly on rocky slopes and sandy sites; frequently cultivated
mezcal_use: One of Oaxaca's rarest commercial agaves with no widespread production, critically endangered, preserved by dedicated mezcaleros
description: Rayo sits low and wide, with stiff and blade-like leaves, toothed edges and a sharp tip that give the whole plant an armoured attitude.

geo_region: Yucatán Peninsula
Terrain: Lowland limestone plains and coastal scrub in the Yucatan; largely cultivated in dry tropical conditions
mezcal_use: Major plantation crop for henequen fiber (ropes, twine); fermented piña used for regional mezcal and pulque; widely cultivated
description: Henequén has sword-like leaves built to handle dry heat. The whole plant looks like it’s wearing an armor of stiff, spined blades.

states: Aguascalientes; Chiapas; Chihuahua; Colima; Ciudad de México; Durango; Guanajuato; Guerrero; Hidalgo; Jalisco; Estado de México; Michoacán; Morelos; Nayarit; Nuevo León; Oaxaca; Puebla; Querétaro; San Luis Potosí; Sinaloa; Sonora; Tabasco; Tamaulipas; Veracruz; Yucatán; Zacatecas
geo_region: Widespread across Mexico (multiple regions and biomes)
Terrain: Sandy soils and gravelly terraces plus rocky slopes in short tree forest and coastal foothills along Mexicos west coast
mezcal_use: Traditional regional mezcal (bacanora) spirit in western Mexico
description: Pacífica is a plant built to take a beating in breezy places and keep its shape, a tight rosette of stiff, narrow, sword like leaves.

geo_region: Sierra Madre Occidental; Northwestern Mexico
Terrain: Pine oak forests at mid to high elevation; grows from cracks in alkaline rocky substrates on steep slopes
mezcal_use: Local mezcal style spirits; minor but documented mezcal species
description: Wocomahi is grounded and stubborn, with a tight rosette of thick, sword like leaves, each one ending in a sharp spine.

geo_region: Western Oaxaca (Sierra Madre del Sur)
Terrain: Tropical dry forest and shrubland plus Quercus forest on volcanic origin soils; rocky slopes and ravines
mezcal_use: Notoriously difficult mezcal species due to saponins; wild harvested
producers: "Del Maguey,Rey Campero,El Jolgorio,Grulani,Mezcal de Leyendas,Creador,La Medida,El Buho,Maguey Melate,Mezcal Colores,Erstwhile,Bozal"
description: Jabalí stays low and stocky, a tight rosette that looks ready to charge. Its stiff, spined leaf edges can look like tusks from the side.

states: Chihuahua; Coahuila; Durango; Jalisco; Nuevo León; Querétaro; San Luis Potosí; Tamaulipas; Zacatecas
geo_region: Chihuahuan Desert and Sierra Madre Oriental (northern Mexico)
Terrain: Semi arid regions on rocky slopes and plains; xeric scrub and open grassland, often on limestone
mezcal_use: Major plantation crop for fiber (ropes, twine); fermented piña used for regional mezcal and pulque; widely cultivated
description: Lamparillo shows up light green with broad, curving leaves that look more ribbon, with rough, grippy texture.

states: Aguascalientes; Chiapas; Chihuahua; Colima; Ciudad de México; Durango; Guanajuato; Guerrero; Hidalgo; Jalisco; Estado de México; Michoacán; Morelos; Nayarit; Nuevo León; Oaxaca; Puebla; Querétaro; San Luis Potosí; Sinaloa; Sonora; Tabasco; Tamaulipas; Veracruz; Yucatán; Zacatecas
geo_region: Widespread across Mexico (multiple regions and biomes)
Terrain: Desert and dry shrubland on well drained sandy or rocky soils; widely cultivated on valley floors and gentle slopes
mezcal_use: Wild form of angustifolia used for rustic mezcals
description: Tepemete forms a dense rosette of narrow, sword-shaped leaves with toothed edges and a sharp terminal needle.

geo_region: Sierra Madre Occidental (Chihuahua-Durango-Sinaloa highlands)
Terrain: Rocky ledges and cliffs; very well drained rock faces and outcrops; often in pine oak country
mezcal_use: Small batch mezcal use; wild-harvested sparingly due to remote habitats
description: Chahuiqui is a tight rosette of narrow leaves, known for threadlike white filaments. The fringe adds a shaggy, tangled edge to a compact plant.

geo_region: Tehuacán-Cuicatlán region
Terrain: Tehuacan Cuicatlan tropical desert on rocky arid slopes and outcrops; very well drained stony soils
mezcal_use: Wild and semi managed mezcal agave; produces bright structured mezcals
description: Espadilla is a compact rosette of stiff, sword like leaves ending sharp spines. Like a bouquet that forgot it was supposed to be soft.

geo_region: Oaxaca (exact subregion TBD; 'Yautepec District' removed because it is not in Oaxaca)
Terrain: Coastal dunes and rocky coastal scrub on sandy to rocky substrates; also cultivated in tropical and subtropical regions
mezcal_use: Endangered, traditional regional mezcal and agave spirit; more often known for fibre but used locally for rustic mezcals
description: Cincoañero grows as a bold rosette; it’s the kind you hunt for. Grown by those who choose care over volume, saved for the truly curious, only.

geo_region: Gulf slope highlands (central Veracruz and adjacent Puebla)
Terrain: Temperate and tropical dry forest on weathering lava flows; rocky well drained slopes and plateaus
mezcal_use: Described as a close relative of Espadín/Oaxacensis, with wild plants often harvested for specialty mezcals labeled Castilla
description: Castilla throws down a flattened rosette with stiff leaves naturally armed with sharp spines.

geo_region: Sierra Sur; Chontal Sierra; Santiago Matatlán; Santa María Ecatepec
Terrain: Unresolved Agave sp.; typically harvested from rocky slopes and canyons in xeric scrub and tropical dry forest; terrain varies by local ID
mezcal_use: Used specifically for small-batch, wild or semi-wild mezcals labeled "Chuparrosa", a hybrid: angustifolia-americana
description: Chuparrosa gets called “Chontal mountain maguey” as it’s tied to Oaxaca’s Chontal region in the Sierra Sur, it's a hummingbird name in Mexico.

geo_region: Central Mexico (Oaxaca, Puebla, Veracruz)
Terrain: High elevation temperate and tropical moist montane forest; cool mountain slopes and forest edges on well drained soils
mezcal_use: Primary species for pulque production; also for mezcal and medicine
description: Pulquero has broad, leather-like leaves flaring from a massive rosette. It is not a dainty plant.

geo_region: Miahuatlán, Sierra Sur, Oaxaca
Terrain: Arid to semi arid scrub and open woodland plus disturbed ground; commonly on rocky slopes and sandy sites; frequently cultivated
mezcal_use: Selected specifically for pulque sap production through heart-tapping; also distilled as regional mezcal
description: Pulque Chino is the century-plant look in real life, a big basal rosette that reads wide, stiff, and classic-spiky.
